explanation:
process_value null-terminates xbuf and then calls MHD_unescape_plus and MHD_http_unescape on that buffer. To determine whether any use of memcmp violates the MISRA rule (i.e., memcmp being used to compare null-terminated strings) you must inspect the implementations that operate on that NUL-terminated buffer: 
- MHD_unescape_plus: called directly with the NUL-terminated xbuf; if this routine uses memcmp/strncmp on the provided buffer (or on other NUL-terminated strings) it could trigger the rule. 
- MHD_http_unescape: called directly with the NUL-terminated xbuf; it may perform comparisons itself or call further helpers that do. 
- MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_: transitively called by MHD_http_unescape and likely does the in-place percent-decoding; any memcmp usage here (or similar comparisons on NUL-terminated data) must be examined.

These three symbols cover the entirety of the call chain from process_value where memcmp misuse could occur; inspecting their source is sufficient to determine whether memcmp is improperly used on null-terminated strings in this path.
